name: Gooey goo goo
description: The special effects used in Symbiosis are curiously similar to some sticky Oscar-winning movies.

key_work.title: Symbiosis
key_work.brief_description:
Symbiosis is an interactive window into another world – one that’s strangely familiar, but alien at the same time. Could you be peering at microscopic cells inside your own body? Or are you seeing two raindrops on a leaf?

In this artwork, Universal Everything make the miniature monumental. Although Symbiosis is made with the same game engine and graphics as some of the other artworks, it doesn’t move as fast. You can slow down and explore how unrushed and deliberate evolution is while you and another person stick, slide and combine to create tiny new life. Or you can bubble on alone, stretching and squelching across the screen as you return to the basic shape that starts all life.

Creative Director: Matt Pyke.
Technical Development and Animation: Chris Mullany.
Sound Design: Simon Pyke.
Executive Producer: Claire Spencer Cook.
Studio Technician: Spike Thompson

constellations_primary.name: Gooey goo goo
constellations_primary.description: The special effects used in Symbiosis are curiously similar to some sticky Oscar-winning movies.

end.title: Flubber
end.creator_credit: Les Mayfield, John Hughes, Ricardo Mestres, Great Oaks and Walt Disney Pictures
end.brief_description: In this colourful remake of ‘The Absent Minded Professor’ (1961), Robin Williams plays Professor Philip Brainard, a brilliant off the wall inventor with an unfortunate short term memory. Flubber, his latest creation is a green rubber-like substance, which has the capacity to give objects flight. Potentially a gold mine for the professor and his college (which is near bankruptcy), the invention receives the unwelcome attention of Brainard’s spiteful nemesis Wilson Croft (Christopher McDonald), who has his own plans for the gravity-defying matter. The romantic subplot which involves a bizarre love triangle between Brainard, his long suffering fiance Sara (Marcia Gay Harden), and a female robot with a jealous streak called Weebo (Jodi Benson), give the film some surprisingly poignant moments, mainly due to Harden’s tender performance. Music by Danny Elfman and screenplay by John Hughes and Bill Walsh.

constellations_other.name: Gooey goo goo
constellations_other.description: The special effects used in Symbiosis are curiously similar to some sticky Oscar-winning movies.

links.description: The oozy, gelatinous characters in Symbiosis are very similar to the sentient green goo in Flubber. Flubber was made by Industrial Light and Magic (ILM), who rose to the challenge of animating a reflective, translucent being with a lot of personality.

end.title: The Absent-Minded Professor
end.creator_credit: Robert Stevenson, Cotton Warburton, Walt Disney, Walt Disney Productions, Bill Walsh and Samuel W. Taylor
end.brief_description: Bumbling professor Ned Brainard accidentally invents flying rubber, or “Flubber”, an incredible material that gains energy every time it strikes a hard surface. It allows for the invention of shoes that can allow jumps of amazing heights and enables a modified Model-T to fly. Unfortunately, no one is interested in the material except for Alonzo Hawk, a corrupt businessman who wants to steal the material for himself.

constellations_other.name: Gooey goo goo
constellations_other.description: The special effects used in Symbiosis are curiously similar to some sticky Oscar-winning movies.

links.description: Flubber is a remake of 1961’s The Absent-Minded Professor, which features Flubber but it’s more like a bouncy ball. Other special effects were done with miniatures, wires and a sodium screen matte process, which layers actors and background footage.

start.title: The Absent-Minded Professor

end.title: Mary Poppins
end.creator_credit: Robert Stevenson, Bill Walsh, Cotton Warburton, Walt Disney, Walt Disney Productions and Don DaGradi
end.brief_description: Mr Banks is looking for a nanny for his two mischievous children and comes across Mary Poppins, an angelic nanny. She not only brings a change in their lives but also spreads happiness.

constellations_other.name: Gooey goo goo
constellations_other.description: The special effects used in Symbiosis are curiously similar to some sticky Oscar-winning movies.

links.description: The Absent-Minded Professor won the Academy Award for Special Effects. Four years later, the inventor of the sodium vapor process, Wadsworth E Pohl, won the Academy Award for Special Effects for Mary Poppins.

end.title: Terminator 2: judgement day
end.creator_credit: James Cameron, Lightstorm Entertainment and Pacific Western
end.brief_description: Sequel to “Terminator”. The story resumes several years later in present day Los Angeles. A cybernetic assassin and bodyguard are sent back from the future. This time the target is John Connor (Edward Furlong), Sarah’s son. The story revolves around the conflict between two Terminators over the the boy’s life and ultimately the future of the human race. Arnold Schwarzenegger and Robert Patrick are suitably impressive and menacing as the two cyborgs, but in the words of James Cameron, the “real” terminator is Linda Hamilton as Sarah Connor. Her transformation from desperate prey, in the original film, to vigilante guerilla is rivetting. At the time of its release, “Terminator 2: Judgement Day” was the most expensive film ever made at a cost of $100 million. Fans of action adventure, mind-boggling special effects and wanton destruction will not be disappointed.

constellations_other.name: Gooey goo goo
constellations_other.description: The special effects used in Symbiosis are curiously similar to some sticky Oscar-winning movies.

links.description: When exploring animation techniques for Flubber, the team at ILM discussed replicating the liquid metal material of the T-1000 robot in Terminator 2: Judgement Day, but since Flubber replicated this was abandoned.

end.title: The Abyss [DVD]
end.creator_credit: James Cameron, Gale Anne Hurd and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
end.brief_description: An American nuclear submarine is mysteriously attacked by an unidentified vessel and when the crew of the submarine go deep into the ocean bed to investigate they find a force so powerful it threatens the future of humankind. Technically a masterpiece, with awesome set designs and special effects, and a chilling soundtrack, “The Abyss” is a terrifying movie. Directed by James Cameron (“Aliens”), “The Abyss” is an extravagantly mannerist example of the science-fiction genre in which the “dark force” is a mirror for the destructive powers which humans unleash on themselves.

constellations_other.name: Gooey goo goo
constellations_other.description: The special effects used in Symbiosis are curiously similar to some sticky Oscar-winning movies.

links.description: Director James Cameron collaborated closely with ILM on his plans for the T-1000, after the company had helped him realise the water-like alien being in his previous film The Abyss, which won the Oscar for Visual Effects.

end.title: Oppenheimer
end.creator_credit: Christopher Nolan, Ellen Mirojnick, Jennifer Lame, Charles Roven, Emma Thomas, Atlas Entertainment, Syncopy, Universal Pictures and Ruth De Jong
end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2023
end.brief_description: The story of J. Robert Oppenheimer’s role in the development of the atomic bomb during World War II.

constellations_other.name: Gooey goo goo
constellations_other.description: The special effects used in Symbiosis are curiously similar to some sticky Oscar-winning movies.

links.description: Another big effects challenge in Terminator 2 was the nuclear explosion, which was done through miniatures, practical effects and a little CGI. In Oppenheimer, the Trinity Test nuclear explosion was made entirely with practical effects.

start.title: Oppenheimer
start.creator_credit: Christopher Nolan, Ellen Mirojnick, Jennifer Lame, Charles Roven, Emma Thomas, Atlas Entertainment, Syncopy, Universal Pictures and Ruth De Jong

end.title: Godzilla Minus One
end.creator_credit: Takashi Yamazaki, Aiko Mizushima, Ryuji Miyajima, Go Abe, Kazuaki Kishida, Keiichiro Moriya, Kenji Yamada, Robot Communications, TOHO, TOHO Studios, Anri Jojo and Tatsuji Nojima
end.brief_description: Postwar Japan is at its lowest point when a new crisis emerges in the form of a giant monster, baptized in the horrific power of the atomic bomb.

constellations_other.name: Gooey goo goo
constellations_other.description: The special effects used in Symbiosis are curiously similar to some sticky Oscar-winning movies.

links.description: While Oppenheimer won seven Oscars, it lost Best Special Effects to Japanese film, Godzilla Minus One. In a symbolic coincidence, Godzilla was created to represent the destruction the atomic bomb had on Japan.
